keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.'
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest, but police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over 20 years ago and is considered a convicted felon under Georgia law.
The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, with over 108 million passengers passing through in 2024, making public safety a high-priority issue.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem expressed concern, with Noem praising law enforcement for preventing a tragedy.
Cartersville police first alerted Atlanta Police after receiving a family report that Cagle was armed and heading to the airport.
Surveillance showed Cagle was already at the airport at the south terminal, drawn to the heavily crowded TSA check-in area.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation, indicating the severity and potential national implications of the event.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Though not armed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle, a convicted felon with a past marijuana offense, faces multiple serious charges including terroristic threats and firearm possession. Authorities were alerted by Cartersville police after a family warning, and surveillance showed Cagle had already arrived at the airport’s south terminal near the crowded TSA check-in area. The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, and the FBI is assisting in the investigation. Officials, including Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, emphasized that the event was a 'tragedy averted' due to early reporting and swift action by law enforcement.
title: Man Arrested Inside Atlanta Airport After Making Threats to ‘Shoot It Up’
